results.title: Gracia Baylor
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Gracia Baylor was the first woman President of the Shire of Healesville, now Yarra Ranges Shire Council, and one of the first two women to be elected to the Victorian Legislative Council. Gracia has been an active leader of women’s organisations, including President of the National Council of Women (NCW) of Victoria 1990-93 and President of NCW Australia 1997-2000. In 1999, Gracia was made a Member of the Order of Australia (AM) in recognition of her services to Parliament and women’s affairs. She is a member of two Federal Government Advisory Committees.

results.title: Victoria: 100 years of progress
results.brief_description:
This documentary looks in detail at the history and development of Melbourne, using artist’s sketches and filmed footage to depict the history of Melbourne. Some items include the Manchester Unity Building, cars of the era travelling down St Kilda Road, St Kilda Beach, a brief history of the Princes Bridge, the Royal Botanic Gardens, Geelong and industries and transport existing in 1934. Also includes footage of the opening of Parliament.

Includes archival footage of early transport-cars; shipping; rail (Flinders Street Station); Prince’s Bridge; St. Kilda Beach; Anzac Parade; Flemington Race Course. Arrival of the Duke and Duchess of York for the first opening of Federal Parliament 1901. Also featured: scenes of the city: Collins and Swanston Streets; Melbourne Town Hill; The Exhibition Building; Parliament House and large private homes in the suburb of Toorak. Reference is made to agricultural and pastoral industries - wheat; wool production; fruit growing and tanning in Mildura. Three masted sailing vessels plus a farewell for the ocean liner Strathnaver. Finally, a re-enactment of gold mining/panning and heralding the first one hundredth birthday of the settlement of Melbourne
[SOURCE: NFSA Collection catalogue)

results.title: Don't tell me I can't
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Krystyna Popczyk
results.brief_description: This is a daughter’s dedication to her mother. Krystina’s mother managed a vision and hearing impairment with great courage and a ‘don’t tell me I can’t’ attitude.

results.title: [Remix: Strike A Pose]
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, ACMI Collections and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to people posing for the camera. A remix of home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection featuring families, fashion models and even a dog, all striking a pose for the camera. On a fashion catwalk, in a parade, on a photoshoot, in a factory or outdoor setting or just the back yard, fashionistas and family folk put their best foot forward from the 1940s to 1970s.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Dried Fruits Australia, Karen Wootton, Elenor Peach, Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office, Jenny & Owen Peake, Tony Agapitos and Ivan Gaal.

results.title: Sharing: the School Community Library
results.creator_credit: Peter Dodds and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: In some Victorian schools joint-use libraries have already been developed where both the school and the community share the same library facilities. This film, for librarians, administrators, and educators examines the problems and advantages of the community library concept as developed at Templestowe Technical School and Nathalia Primary School.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Dodds and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.description: In some Victorian schools joint-use libraries have already been developed where both the school and the community share the same library facilities. results.title: From Graz to Glenroy
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Elfrieda Senycia and Viv Mehes
results.brief_description: This story explores the journey of migration from Austria to Australia for Elfrida and her husband. As they rebuild life in a new country they deal with triumps and disappointments including the humiliation of never having their qualifications recognised in Australia.

results.title: In conversation with Al Alcorn
results.brief_description:
Al Alcorn talks with Swinburne University’s Christian McCrea about the origin of Atari, the culture from which it emerged and the legacy of ‘Pong’.
Interviewed on 07 March 2008 as part of the ‘Game On’ exhibition.
